item.title: Character input
item.dc:creator: @Tree Tree
item.description:
@Tree wrote:

ytuio9`:

Yeah shame on you all for helping people… I hope you learned your lesson. If I ever see you helping someone again I will be reporting you to MoparIsTheBest.

You’re an idiot. Let’s take a look at some of the previous posts in this section.

Do you see the amount of topics created by V1 after he was spoon fed? He has become reliant on others. He’s incapable of using outside resources because he’s never been directed to them before.

[quote="_s, post:17, topic:435512"][quote author=Tree link=topic=538231.msg3939400#msg3939400 date=1331296669]
A solution could have been found by simply reading a few chapters of ‘The Really Big Index’.
Don’t promote spoon feeding. Instead, direct him to the required learning resources. You should all know better.
[/quote]you should know better than to expect an average moparscaper to actually be able to deduce a solution to his problem without spoonfeeding.[/quote]

I’ve coached plenty of people here. There’s always room for improvement.

item.title: Character input
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:11, topic:435512”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=538231.msg3939168#msg3939168 date=1331267318]

the amount of stupidity in this thread is quite heartbreaking.

ps: as zyle1992 pointed out, chars are bytes and bytes are chars

In the ASCII encoding. Although, depending on what language you’re programming in, or what language the machine is running it may have unexpected results (although, English is the suggested programming language).
[/quote]
yes and they both have the same range too[/quote]
Off-topic… isn’t it just a conversion, not encoded? 01100001 is ‘a’, because it’s 97… I never really understood whether that was considered ‘encoded’ or just converted.

item.title: Character input
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote=“Native^, post:7, topic:435512”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=538231.msg3937460#msg3937460 date=1331156694]

final Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);
char c = 0;
do {
    c = (char) scanner.nextByte();
    switch (c) {
        case 'y':
        case 'Y':
            // do stuff
            break;
    }
}
while (c != 'q');

[/quote]
This if you want to keep the program running.[/quote]

First time I’ve seen a do-while statement in a long time. :S

For Java input, I usually utilize a while loop and add if statements in it as command handling.

Read full topic

item.title: Character input
item.dc:creator: @Native1 Native^
item.description:
@Native1 wrote:

Aight, soo.
First create a Scanner object. Or any InputStream, but Scanner works fine.

Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);

Then you will have to read the next character input. But since there’s no method for reading one character. We read a byte and upcast to a character. Now the good thing about this method is that it blocks, it pauses the program, until it has found a character.

char c = (char)scanner.nextByte();

Then you have two if statements or a switch.

if(c == 'n') {
   System.out.println("You've inserted the character 'n'");
   /* Rest of body here. */
}
if(c == 'y') {
   System.out.println("You've inserted the character 'y'");
   /* Rest of body here. */
}

You’re welcome bro.

Read full topic

System.out.println("if this is correct type 'y' if not type 'n'"); Scanner redo = new Scanner(System.in); redo.nextLine(); if(redo.nextLine() == y){
